This prevents Bb5 after c5, so now I'm doing something at least!
Whew, a breath!
Whew, a breath!
Strange move, but this N is aiming to harass my lsb, and it's dangerous: after Ng3, I can't play Bg6, or f5 will win it.
I'll see later. Now I'm developing with tempo, threatening lsb and pinning the d pawn in return to white.

Here it comes. Now, what can I do? If I save my B on g4, he will save his on b2 - a very strong B! while mine will be fatally exchanged badly for a N after h3. So, the answer was only one: the risky one, as always.
...so I won a pawn in the process. But my developement problems are not solved!
...so I won a pawn in the process. But my developement problems are not solved!
...so I won a pawn in the process. But my developement problems are not solved!
Finally! but still, my dsb has no good place to go to...
Finally! but still, my dsb has no good place to go to...

This is a doubled-edged move, but I felt I had to do something or languish. I won't be able to take anything with the c pawn until the R is protected, but he won't because of the pin on the Q. If he releases it, I'll use the tempo. At any exchange, I have b5, and if the Q is still on c, the piece will be pinned. Very interesting, for my standards.
Looking for a Q's exchange, after which the game changes and looks pretty equal and very technical. Nope...
Self-blocking his lsb, but depriving me from the e4 square. Anyway, if Ne4, NxN and even after dxN, Nd2, f5, I don't feel I achieve too much.

!? I want space. I can't take, but I can still push it, for example...
Good! The threat of Rb1 is stronger than my grip on the g column. I can lose b7.
? In sight of Rb1.
But my opponent is not any better than me, so he played...
...and this gave me tempo to defend, somewhat, b7. In fact, I think I'm lost here with accurate play from white.
